docs.lead_paragraph: Nowhere is the American health care system more broken and desperate than rural Mississippi. Which is why an approach born in a broken and desperate place — Iran — may offer the best chance of saving lives.
docs.snippet: Nowhere is the American health care system more broken and desperate than rural Mississippi. Which is why an approach born in a broken and desperate place — Iran — may offer the best chance of saving lives.

docs.lead_paragraph: A federal lawsuit is trying to block an extreme and harmful Arizona anti-abortion law from taking effect next week. We hope it succeeds.
docs.abstract: Editorial supports federal lawsuit aiming to block Arizona's extreme anti-abortion law, which sets the earliest deadline for abortions in the country; points out law is unconstitutional, and represents a serious health threat to women who experience dangerous complications during a wanted pregnancy.
docs.snippet: A federal lawsuit is trying to block an extreme and harmful Arizona anti-abortion law from taking effect next week. We hope it succeeds.

headline.main: When Publicity Precedes Peer Review in the Fight Over Gas Impacts

docs.abstract: A scary study pointing to prenatal health risks from fracking gets publicized before peer review.
docs.snippet: A scary study pointing to prenatal health risks from fracking gets publicized before peer review.

headline.main: For an Adoptee Parent, Breastfeeding as Revelation

docs.abstract: I was the fourth generation in my birth family to be given away, and for me, breastfeeding is less "natural" than new.
docs.snippet: I was the fourth generation in my birth family to be given away, and for me, breastfeeding is less "natural" than new.

headline.main: From Unbridled Optimism to Empty Nests

docs.abstract: Dona Schwartz's double project, "On the Nest" and "Empty Nesters," shows parents on either end of their child-rearing odysseys.
docs.snippet: Dona Schwartz's double project, "On the Nest" and "Empty Nesters," shows parents on either end of their child-rearing odysseys.

docs.lead_paragraph: A reader, returned from Shanghai, discusses Chinese women’s lack of access to health care.
docs.snippet: A reader, returned from Shanghai, discusses Chinese women’s lack of access to health care.

docs.lead_paragraph: Concern is mounting that the ''breast is best'' dogma is creating undeserved guilt and serious hardships for a growing number of new mothers, many of whom work full time and cannot afford, professionally or financially, the prolonged maternity leaves needed to breast-feed their infants for the time now recommended. Forty-three years ago, when my twin sons were born, the pressure to breast-feed exclusively for six months was not as strong as it is today. I nonetheless felt I had let them - and myself - down when this proved impossible. I had looked forward to feeding only breast milk for the six months of maternity leave my job allowed. But nature had a different plan.

headline.main: Personal Health: The Ideal and the Real of Breast-Feeding

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column notes mounting concern that campaigns to encourage mothers to breastfeed may be creating undeserved guilt and hardships for a growing number of new mothers; holds that many mothers cannot afford, professionally or financially, the prolonged maternity leaves needed to breast-feed their infants for the time now recommended. Drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Concern is mounting that the ''breast is best'' dogma is creating undeserved guilt and serious hardships for a growing number of new mothers, many of whom work full time and cannot afford, professionally or financially, the prolonged maternity leaves...

docs.lead_paragraph: After MaryAnn and Drew Szilagyi, a Houston couple in their early 30s, saw their physician for routine physicals a few years ago, they didn't have to wait for his call about the blood work. Just two days later, Mr. Szilagyi, a banker, logged onto a Web site, perused his lab results and sighed with relief. All normal. But when Mrs. Szilagyi, who sells luxury kitchen equipment, followed suit, no results were displayed. Instead, a message flashed: Contact Doctor's Office.

headline.main: When Health's at Stake, Waiting Is Hardest Part

docs.abstract: Changes in federal regulations may soon allow patients to get the results of important medical tests quickly online, bypassing the nerve-wracking process of waiting for a doctor's telephone call; many experts are concerned that pervasive direct access to test results may have serious drawbacks, leaving patients even more confused and overwhelmed by information they do not know how to interpret. Drawing (M)
